reviewText:
TLR is well known as Core Design's swansong. That one last good title they made before releasing the godawful Chronicles and Angel of Darkness.

Tomb Raider the Last Revelation takes place in one singular location rather than different parts of the world. While that might seem like a downside, the design team actually implemented it very well. The game gradually branches out and becomes heavily non-linear. With the player returning to prior maps to solve newly found puzzles. They also added a map editor, and since the 90s hundreds of maps have been published online

Add to that a great story that keeps your attention and genuinely challenging puzzles. Delight yourself to the Last Revelation, ultimately the last great Tomb Raider game.
voteText: 49 of 51 people (96%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If there's one thing I can say about The Last Revelation, it's that it surprised me greatly. I'd be lying if I said that my expectations weren't low for the fourth entry into the immortal Tomb Raider series. No Croft Manor? No Judith Gibbins as the voice actress for Lara? No inventory ring? No musical score by the awesome Nathan McCree? No locking Winston in the freezer? All these charming little things from the previous games that up and left with The Last Revelation had me thinking that I would be quite disappointed with Core Design's next foray into the adventures of Indiana Jane and the Breasts of Enormity. It's not often that I like being proven wrong, but I can happily say that The Last Revelation surpassed my expectations and proved why I can't keep myself away from this excellent series.

While it is sad to see the previously mentioned elements missing from this installment, the gameplay itself is still the stellar, straight-forward and damn fun formula players have grown accustomed to in the last three games. Lara returns with all her previous manouvres, and a few new ones to boot, including rope-swinging, shimmying around corners and pole-climbing. Nothing groundbreaking, but hey, if it ain't broke, don't fix it. The Last Revelation has seemingly taken a few pages from Resident Evil's book. There's a largely increased emphasis on puzzles and riddles, some of which are quite complex. This is a well thought out departure from Tomb Raiders 1-3, in which pretty much every puzzle boiled down to find keys to open this door so you can open that door to get that key to pull this switch". You can also now combine certain items and vision-based items such as binoculars and scopes are frequently used. Some weapons also have multiple ammo types which is a lovely added touch.

The Last Revelation is also the most accessible game in the series since the first. I loved the slow but steady learning curve of the original release

reviewText:
There aren't many adults that don't know about Tomb Raider. TRIV (when compared to TRIII) has advanced lighting effects (volumetric FX, bump mapping), better texture filtration and a new UI. The game is slightly less linear, since at some points you can travel between the levels (almost like open world, eh?) back and forth, the game has 70 secrets (there's no reward for getting all of them, but you get good rewards for each one of them). This time the story focuses on Egypt, where Lara unwillingly sets god Set free. Will you help her to save the world? Also the game has a standalone bonus level called Times exlusive" which you can download for free.

There's also a widescreen patch that allows you to play in 16:9 and other aspect ratios. You can get it at http://agent077.ho.ua/

In a perfect world this should be played after finishing:
- Tomb Raider (I)
- Tomb Raider: Unfinished Business
- Tomb Raider II
- Tomb Raider II: The Golden Mask
- Tomb Raider III: Adventures of Lara Croft
- Tomb Raider III: The Lost Artifact"

reviewText:
Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation continues the adventures of Lara Croft. After a tutorial with young Ms. Croft, we find Lara and a guide exploring the Tomb of Seth in Egypt, looking for the Amulet of Horus. The plot revolves around Egyptian Gods, Pyramids, ancient artifacts of power, and actual tomb raiding! The previous 2 sequels to TR1 WERE enjoyable but TR IV is the one that really gets back to its roots. This game is all about exploring Egypt's tombs and ruins. Lara visits the Temple of Karnak, the Tomb of Semerkhet, the Temple of Isis, and Cleopatra's Palaces - to name a few places. And don't think she's just raiding. The Last Revelation has a very interesting and intense story.

Controls: Same as TR 1-3

Graphics: Definite improvement over 3

Music: All new Egyptian-themed music for IV

Differences from TR 1-3: There is a LOT to explore. Instead of completing an area and moving onto the next, you'll often have to revisit areas - moving back and forth to complete puzzles and solve Egypt's mysteries.

I'm a huge Tomb Raider fan so it goes without saying that I'm recommending this. However, even if you're not familiar with any of the older TRs, if you're an action/adventure fan or interested in exploring ancient Egypt, I believe you'll really enjoy this.
voteText: 27 of 27 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Tomb Raider 4: The Last Revelation was the best TR game in my opinion. Why? Because it was a Tomb Raider game since the first one that was actuall about exploring tombs and fighting monsters (With a little appearence of bad guys). That said, let's go to the topics:

Graphics: Pretty good for a 1999 game, actually. Texture variation is not so present because ambient is also not. That's because you will be put in on closed spaces more than open ones. Pyramids, temples and hidden tombs will be more seen than anything else. But the presentation of these places are actually nice, it doesn't get repetitive and you always know when a place is new or not.

Gameplay: Picking up the style from the other TR games, it remained the same with a few additions. Lara can now jump into ropes, walk in them and best of all: DRIVE VEHICLES! That was a nice little adition, tough i din't find the vehicles gameplay so pleasurable for me. At least at a long time ago. For me, now isn't that bad. It's pretty ok.
Gunplay feels the same from other games and doging from enemies still feels impossible, tough, as in other games, exploring is the key too fill up with medkits and ammo. Not much problem here.
Puzzles are back and were the main focus of the game. You will waste more time on puzzles than killing enemies. They are complex, but not hard to do.
Remember when i said i couldn't remember if the secrets followed the same pattern as TR 5? Yeah, it follows. Global statistics for secrets, no statistics per stage. And this game is HUGE, it is a big flaw to make harder to find the secrets in this game. At least, you don't win anything by finding it all, besides new weapons/items on your gameplay. Exploration is the key, once again.

Soundtrack: More or less. Most of the time you will only hear ambient sounds. But when music plays, it always match with what's happening and feels like an epic adventure. Voice acting is quite decent and Lara's voice is sweet.

Story: Here was the big point of this game. The plot tried to explore a bit of Lara's past at the beggining and tried to connect to the actual story that was happening. It went pretty well and many things have been done. A lot of effort was put in the Seth and Horus backstory and as more as you explore, more content is revealed. The game goes roughly for a lot of time because of this. It all went you...Until the ending. The boss battle felt so empty for me and the ending itself was quite sad and a cliffhanger.

TR 4 was the best game of the franchishe for me and it was pleasurable to play. The focus on the adventure more than action served this game well for me and it made an unique experience.
If devs that are doing the new Tomb Raider were to see a game where they could see what they SHOULD do with the series style of play, it should be this one.

reviewText:
Back to the roots and forward in the history of the egypt ancients!Hint: At the end of this review you will find a TL;DR and video section.

----------------------------------------------------------------

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
Released through Eidos Interactive in 1999 for PC, Playstation 1 and Dreamcast, Core Design developed Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation with the idea to come back to the original. It shouldn't be as linear as the other games before, but the gameplay itself had to be spiked with many puzzles, as fans of Tomb Raider I missed for a long time. Ancient temples and ruins are meant to be discovered once again and till that date it turned out to be Lara's biggest adventure.

It is the year 1984. Professor Werner Von Croy is on his expedition to Kambodscha to find an artefact called The Iris". The young Lara
recommended: reads about it in an edition from "National Geographic" and her volition to hunt for this artefact awakens. Lord Croft funded the expedition and so Lara is allowed to follow Von Croy on his exploring journey. Lara will soon find out that "The Iris" is just the start and gets a big ball rolling by her artefact hunt.\n\nWhat would be a new Tomb Raider game without new features and improved graphics? Since Tomb Raider III the overall look of the surrounding stood nearly the same. Yet
hoursPlayed: the developer smoothed out Lara's apperance with less blocks in her polygones and draw attention to the 3D effects like water surface
voteText: ambient lighting and fog. Lara got also a moving mouth in the ingame cutscenes
helpfulPercent: which are admittedly not very in sync to what she is saying but still
votesHelpful: she appears a bit more alive now. The 3D cutscenes between the levels are well made and also highly detailed as usual.\n\nLara's arsenal changed once again. Like in every Tomb Raider game the pistols -still with unlimited ammo- uzi
votesTotal: grenadelauncher and shotgun are the same with a minimal reskin. The desert eagle from Tomb Raider III is replaced by the revolver and the crossbow found its way into the arsenal. New is the possibility to change the kind of ammunition for the shotgun
votesFunny: grenadelauncher and crossbow. Also a lasersight can be attached to the revolver and crossbow
commentsCount: which is required in some levels to solve a puzzle. While pressing 0 on the numpad the player will enter a sniper-like view to shoot accurate manually.\n\nLara's moves are extended again
column16: which include the abillity to climb around edges and swing on robes.\nThe menu got a complete new reskin
column17: everything is now on one page and can be highlighted by sidescrolling. Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation is also the first Tomb Raider game with destructible objects such as wooden barricades and jars
column18: which contain often ammunition and medikits.\nOne thing that the previous games taught the player is now to erase from the memories: While closed doors were really shut and only possible to open by activating a button or a lever
column19: Lara is now able to open some doors by her own
column20: sometimes with the help of a crowbar. Don't let closed doors fool you.\n\nAs already mentioned
column21: Tomb Raider IV is spiked with many intelligent puzzles
column22: not only based on moving a block from A to B. Lara is able to combine items she has found on her journey and will reveal new ways of puzzle solving. The compass in the menu will help with some puzzles as well and even a fun minigame will let the heart from fans of this franchise leap with joy.\n\nThe linearity moved a bit away for those who like to discover on her own but with this comes the problem of easy missable objective items and cluelessness inside some levels. It was meant to change the gameplay but also harshly increases the difficulty of it. Also the backtracking irritates often
column23: because there are mostly no hints what the player has to do. Thanksfully there are a lot of walkthroughs and guides out there
column24:
so the player does not need to stumble in the complete dark.

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
The fourth part of the franchise wasn't new for me
column25: so the gameplay wasn't blind as well. Yet
column26: after all these years I forgot a few parts of it and with the backtracking and less linearity I had trouble to find all objective items in one go.  However
column28: the intelligent puzzles and incredible awesome levels compensate for this problem and with 35 levels (36 with the bonus level) the length of it was satisfying enough.\n\nTomb Raider IV: The Last revelation is by far my favourite of the 5 classic games
column29:
directly after Tomb Raider II of course. Worth playing for every fan of this franchise and for those who want to know how the young Lara started her artefact hunt.

reviewText: This is definitely my favourite Tomb Raider game to date - it's classic Lara, with some of the most fiendish puzzles in the series and an awesome storyline to bring it all together. The introduction of linked levels that you can travel back and forth through at your leisure brings a totally new dimension to the game, and although it can start to feel a little long-winded towards the end, it's entirely worth it to be able to see all the gorgeous levels and experience the story. As long as you're prepared for a little frustration when it comes to a few puzzles, this game is Lara's best.

reviewText:
First of all this game is good. You get everything you'd expect from Tomb Raider game (unless you're looking for next-gen graphics).

I loved some of the new mechanics and new puzzles.
By the way puzzles are even more complex sometimes (at least for me) and I could not figure out how to solve some of them so I resorted to some walkthroughs. And what makes it even more time consuming is that the game lets you to 2-3 levels and you can go back. And sometimes you will need to go back because you didn't find some item. Which can be frustrating sometimes. And some puzzle elements are not as apparent as in previous games.

Other than that I really enjoyed the game but I would have liked it more if there was more shooting in the game.

So if you are a fan of Tomb Raider pick this one up and have a good time.

reviewText:
When it comes to the exciting outings of Lara, Core Design's 'The Last Revelation' is, for me, the pinnacle of the Tomb Raider series.

As a fresh return to the series' roots, the fourth game focuses more on high adventure and exciting exploration, sending the player on an epic journey across ancient locations in Egypt to resolve a prophecy that spans millennia.

Gone are gloomy London skylines and secret military installations of the previous two games. Instead of diving into underwater bases, Lara will delve into ancient tombs and mysterious ruins. You'll search for archaic artifacts instead of keycards, dodging devious traps and whirling blades, instead of laser wires and auto-turrets. The game still has plenty of frenetic gunplay, with new weapons, ammo choices and smarter enemies. But exploration and puzzles take centre stage here.

The atmosphere is fantastic. You'll feel isolated as you tiptoe through dark corridors, treading where no foot as stepped for centuries. The graphics are a step up, but the sound makes the most impact. Musical cues still feature, but for the most part you'll hear nothing but your own footsteps, the wind rolling through passageways, and the occasional crumble of stones somewhere in the distance. Exploration has never been so exciting or tense!

The game is well balanced. Tomb Raider 3 often had me wandering aimlessly around, not  sure where to go; Levels were completed almost by accident. Here, everything makes sense: You'll always know the item you need to proceed - even if you don't know where it is. The puzzles are challenging, but never tedious trial and error. A great feat, considering puzzles can span multiple levels and require multiple items. You'll rarely find yourself backtracking simply to see if you missed a hidden switch or obscure item.

Overall, the game provides the series' best adventure. It gets the important parts right, and brings enough fresh features to keep the series interesting. Highly recommended.

reviewText: This is by far one of my favorite Tomb Raider games. Lara explores Egypt, a country shrouded in deep mystery,  and tries to thwart the evil Set from unleashing his darkness upon the world. The events that lead up to the key and cliffhanger ending are among the most engaging of all the Tomb Raider games. No matter f it is a classic game with obsolete graphics, it still holds its own and then some among hard core Tomb Raider followers around the globe! A must have for any true Tomb Raider fan!

reviewText:
To all the Tomb Raider fans out there, I must apologise for my crass words, but to sum up this game as succinctly as possible:

This Game is a Turd.

Starting off very well, going back to the adventure roots of the original Tomb Raider, I was pleasantly delighted. Ok, other than Lara having a Makeover and some swanky new lighting affects, the graphics haven't changed much at all over the last four games, the Gameplay is still more or less the same use of awkward controls, but there is still a diamond in the rough here. I was having fun!

And then came levels like Alexandria.

Whoever says Tomb Raider has good level design is lying or mad... or likely both. It consists of the most random level plans, unexplained puzzles (that even after reading Tutorials make absolutely no sense whatsoever in the context of the time, the language, the culture).

Sorting out the random hieroglyphics into the English alphabet, and then putting it into alphabetical order. But Why? Why in alphabetical order to start with? There is no hint given as to why, it just is... but even worse... our Alphabet came into being a couple of thousand years after this tomb was built!

So these great people of Egypt, with their time travel machines, glimpsed into the future, saw our Alphabet, then amazingly decided to change all of their language and hieroglyphics to be matching one of our letters (which essentially means that the Egyptians wrote in English, but used pictures as representation for each letter... no Core, that is not how it is. That is truly terrible puzzle design.

Ah hell, why bother trying to even explain it.

This game feels like something a 11 year old would make today in his lunch break at school. It feels like one persons over exited child was in charge of building levels, while the entire rest of the staff worked on the CGI films, that for it's time were pretty steller, to tie in some nonsensical plot that is very much from a time where games were not story tellers... ah hell, but they tried.

So the levels are random, convoluted, blocky horribleness that have actually gotten worse with every single iteration of the series. I can hear the games director's demands:

New engine? NAH! new gameplay ideas? NAH! what we need is
recommended: MORE COMPLICATED BUG RIDDEN LEVELS THAT NO ONE WILL BE ABLE TO COMPLETE WITHOUT A WALKTHROUGH." ... Genius.\n\nTalking of which
hoursPlayed: to all the fans who will  undoubtedly vote me down
voteText: how many of you completed this game without a walk-through?\n\nYeah
helpfulPercent: I can hear the tumble weeds bouncing down the street too.\n\nThe only person who ever completed this without help
votesHelpful: was the person who wrote the official walkthrough... but even that's not true
votesTotal: as he had help from Core. If the standard user can not finish your game without a walkthrough
votesFunny: no matter how smart you are (as these puzzles have absolutely NOTHING to do with intelligence) then you game is broken. There is no arguing around that.\n\nThere is a reason that the beloved Tomb Raider
commentsCount: PSX's best original series died (as it was) along with Core. Good riddance!\n\n2/10 (and it only get's above a 1 because

reviewText:
I may only have 7 hours in this game in Steam, but when I was a kid up until being about 15, I'd play this game on my wrecked PS2 every day when I came home. I think I must have completed it about 30 times.

This game is my favourite game of all time. From the title screen music to the final boss fight, there isn't a moment that isn't amazing, challenging or just lovably goofy (read: The Guardian). The story is meh, but the level design and locations are just so, so great.

I'm not sure if it's just childhood nostalgia, but I'd recommend this game to anyone anywhere. It's what got me into gaming, and years later I'm still enjoying it even though I know it back to front.

Do yourself a favour and try this out. It's pretty cheap, so you're really getting your worth and then some.

reviewText: Some of the most consistently well-designed levels in the series, taking a break from the ridiculously contrived settings in Tomb Raider III and II, and a more well-connected world map which changes the structure of the game make Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation a real treat to play. Pretty much all of the levels are connected, now, and with the addition of the need to backtrack, this game is structured quite differently, almost a bit like a metroidvania, albeit without the vertical elements. Add to that several good additions like shattering pots with your gun, or aiming down a gun's sights, and this game's probably, nostalgia aside, the best entry in the first 6 Tomb Raider games.

reviewText: The first Tomb Raider was one of my own first eye-openers to gaming, aside from the cliche Wolfenstein and anything Sierra put out in the 80's-90's.  This game took me somewhere, like Quake did for the FPS to me, and fully immersed me.  This title and Chronicles and Angel of Darkness, I never got to experience, yet they are like re-experiencing that first game again.  In all that entails.. the controls?  Wow, how did I do this back then?  My hands have adapted to controllers or at least mouse support.  Still.. I give this a solid 9/10.. +1.5 for nostalgia.

reviewText: I used to play this with my sister in the early 2000s. We never finished it back then, not until last year when I completed the Steam version - which is by far the best looking one. The atmosphere, the Egypt story and the old school platformer gameplay makes this arguably the best TR ever made. In some ways it's a scary game, you're alone and the focus is on exploring the environment, avoiding deadly traps while solving puzzles. If you thought the new TR was easy and too action oriented, I recommend playing this game. To put it another way; TR4 demonstrates an era of gaming when game developers made their games very challenging, a level of challenge that would trouble today's casual gamers, but definitely a very fun experience especially if you're a gamer from that era. 9/10

reviewText:
Mean Mr. Mustard's short Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation review

1) Essential - buy it NOW
2) Recommended - buy it on sale 3) Avoid

Time to complete – 23 hours to 100% (used a guide for some of the secrets as the game no longer tells you on a level-by-level basis how many you have)
Played multiplayer? N/A
Worth revisiting? Yes, I enjoy replaying the entire original TR series once every few years or so

Best part – More classic TR gameplay, although with this entry the signs are starting to appear that the developers were starting to feel burnt out. Still, well worth playing.
Worst part – Needs some tweaking on modern systems to get it working properly (for all required patches see: http://tombraiders.net/stella/downloads/TR4files.html)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I grew up playing Tomb Raider games, with Lara Croft being an awesome main character. However, after picking this title back up again, I'm left slightly disappointed.

Without giving too much away, the story progresses wonderfully. I was expecting the same for the finale, but was given a lackluster conclusion.

What this game does offer are unique puzzles that challenge even modern video games with their difficulty. If you've played the more recent Tomb Raiders, playing this will likely feel very different.

Despite me being left sour with the ending, I still recommend this game. Beating it is an accomplishment (without a walkthrough!) I estime my actual play time being closer to 30 hours. I have a bad habit of leaving my games running.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about TR4, but overall I think its an improvement on the earlier games.

In this there is a very marked improvement in the graphics, most noticeably on Lara, who is no longer a series of disjointed cubes and polygons. On top of this there are more varied environemtns, with less of a 'blocky' feel to them. Also, playing these games on a modern computer, TR4 is the first one where there haven't been any major problems while playing the FMV cutscenes. The game still has some issues playing at higher resolutions, but that is only to be expected.

In addition to this, there is an improvement in the storytelling, I find. This game is the first where everything seems to follow a logical storyline, and the use of fmv and in-level cutscenes does a good job of telling this. Rather than jumping everywhere around the world, you stay in Egypt, which I feel gives the game more of a chance to build up the story than the previosu ones, which jumped about a lot.

One down side to this game is that it has a lot fo the two things which I like the least about tomb raider games: Vehicles and Backtracking. If you've played a TR game before, you know how bad the vehicles are. Clunky and terrible, but you need to them to progress the level. The back tracking isn't too bad in this game, so I guess that's more a matter of personal preference.

The controls are not said to support xbox controllers, but it actually is possible to use one without resorting to a third-party tool, although you need to manually configure it, and it only seems to support one analog stick.

All in all, if you are new to TR and want to play one of the earlier TR games, I think this would be a good one to play.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I believe In hindsight that Tomb Raider II and III were missteps for the franchise.
Eidos basically forced Core design to crank these games out on an annual basis and it shows.
The first two sequels strayed too far from what made the original great. Tombs were replaced with modern architecture and wild animals with an over abundance of gun toting muscle men.
Thankfully The Last Revelation gets the series back on track and feels to me like it should have been the second game rather than the fourth.
Every ounce of the original Playstation's power was wrung in order to improve the graphics. If you compare the character model of Lara from the 1996 original to the one in Tomb Raider IV you will see a marked improvement.
Modern locations like opera houses and submarine bases have been replaced for pyramids and tombs.
The entire story takes place in one location this time (Egypt) and the experience feels all the batter for it.
I'm quite disappointed that controlling Lara often feels like driving a bus still. The controls and lack of a free camera are infuriating. Nintendo cracked the basic formula for free camera with Super Mario 64 three years earlier, perhaps if Eidos had allowed Core more time between releases they could have created a new engine or at least improved upon the clunky fixed camera mechanisms for the original.
I don't know who is leaving gun ammo and health packs in ancient tombs and vases  but it's a little rediculous. Couldn't a more realistic system have been designed at this point; it breaks the fantasy.
Finally, this game's tutorial section fails to explain all of the new gameplay mechanisms so players may find themselves scratching their heads later on. For example, how was I supposed to know that binoculars have an infrared feature that when used can highlight hidden writing at certain points in the game when the tutorial never explained it to me and none of the previous games had this feature?
Tomb Raider IV also allows the player to revisit previous levels. Great, but it also allows the player to leave a section without an item they will need to complete the game later on and then prevents them from returning. There is no warning, so make sure you have plenty of save files just in case!

In conclusion, a good game, better than Tomb Raider II and III, but let down by, ironically, a lack of necessary handholding.

8/10
